comments.commentBody:
"However, the Palestinian people shop and stroll the streets of Israel without batting "

Huh? You need to check your information here. Only a handful of Palestinians from the WB have work permits to work or visit Israel, and non of the 1.7 million Gazans are allowed to travel, period. You may be confusing Israeli-Arab citizens with the over 4 million Palestinians in the occupied territories.

You should read MONDOWEISS to learn what goes on there. Many Israelis regularly visit Palestinian villages. How do you think we get to learn the day to day realities of the territories if it weren't for people from Israeli NGOs?

The word "Folk" is from the Old English word "Folc." It is a common way to refer to people in the U.S, and I hear it used almost daily in California--not sure if it is used in the same manner in the rest of the country, but I would guess so. With only one syllable, it is a graceful word deriving of Germanic provenance. What's to offend?

I can think of another reason the 0.1% (or 0.01%) would welcome a depression, whether caused by a rise in interest rates or something else: depressed asset prices, notably assets that retain their power to produce in the long run. A golden opportunity to scarf up cheaply more of the source of future wealth!

With all due respect I am not sure Wikipedia is the most reliable source to be relying upon..... The past has happened, Israel was formed, that wont be changed. The problem is the continued "settlement" expansion, oppression of the arabs who live in israel and the Israeli justification that they are trying their best to come to a two state solution which is completely contradictory. Why haven't they ever set hard border and why do they continually encroach further into what was originally palestinian territory? I am neither pro israel or pro palestinian, it is far more complex then someone who isn't living it could understand. I would point you to a comment from a Molly in san diego below who's sister lives this life. She makes some extremely valid points about israel's position, They are obviously the more powerful party, they have the power to make peace if they want to.
Given the pictures of the cows, shouldn't Arlo's lyric be "dogies"?  (Of course, it should be "lie down," so all bets are off.)

DL, Arlo's pop Woody wrote that song and you're 100% correct the subject is of the bovine persuasion, not canine. As the cowpokes are nearing a "packing house town" the lyric and slideshow tell of the certain fate of those dogies. Witness the tin cans. Sad, but true. Temple Grandin still fights for the ethical and humane treatment of livestock at the 'packing houses' Woody wrote about.

Towing before TOWAGE made for a SWEATY solve with lots ARCANE stuff. POPO, BARCA and the wine keg were TERMS I couldn't come to grips with ERGO a fail, one for the DOGGYs. First Arlo, then Warren Haynes address the DOGGY; one with a lullaby and the other with a rocker sure to wake you from any slumber.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NEcFQt8fZDY

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IXJK00r6a-s

T.G.I. FRIDAY,

Bru

Displaying your Jewishness does not grant you the right to distort facts and paint an inaccurate picture. Jews have been pushed around for millennia. They were pushed out of the ancient land of Israel, they were pushed out of Spain, England, and Russia well before the "near annihilation" of the Jews in Europe. Then they were pushed out of their homes in north African Arab countries and elsewhere. Immigration doors were slammed in their faces around the world, including and most tragically by the US.

To paint the birth of the state of Israel as a "profound tragedy" is hyperbole of the highest and worst degree. Tell us about the history of North America, South America, Australia, New Zealand and the plight of the truly indigenous people in those areas, then tell us about how many of those colonists were returning to their ancestral homeland after being brutalized for centuries in their adopted homelands. Tell us about how those colonists had few other if any areas to go to where they had the hope of no longer being threatened by their own governments. Then tell us how many of those countries in all those lands were voted into being by an international governing body. This lip-service myth that the birth of Israel pushed others off their land ignores the rhetoric and aggression of the Arabs to destroy the nascent state of Israel.

The Jewish people have chosen to no longer be pushed around, and have chosen to no longer wait for their enemies to attack.

I agree with your point. If the leaders of Gaza and Palestine focused on improving the lives of their citizens, rather than on making war against Israel, much good could be accomplished. And if a peaceful two state (or three state, if Gaza were made independent) solution could be realized, I am confident that Israel would be much relieved to be free of its policing duties.

A political solution in the MIddle East could be arranged along the following lines:
--Recognition of Israel by Palestine, Hamas, Hezbollah and the Arab world.
--Withdrawal of Israel to its 1967 borders, with negotiated amendments.
--Partition of Jerusalem or governance of Jerusalem by the United Nations.

Of course, many extremists have refused to accept the first point.

What buffer? Hamas missiles can reach essentially all of Israel! Until the people of the Gaza realize that fighting is futile the cycle will continue. Hamas took over the territory by force and after killing countless Fatah members. Since then, the only buffer they have respected is at the tip of missiles. Only crushing Hamas will end the cycle. Israel should reoccupy and stay around till they are certain Hamas is finished, then Gaza can rejoin the more level headed Palestinian organization. I disapprove strongly of Israeli "peace" tactics but if its blood Hamas wants then by all means they should get it. You cant kill a sea star by injuring one of its arms you have to kill the body.

If I could actually buy it and impose tolls, I think it would constitute a good investment. Even at the 2014 $ cost of the original construction.
Bernanke is being paid big bucks because he was the ultimate insider on monetary policy. Anything he says in public that might put pressure to raise interest rates, even if it has to be 'spinned'. Hence, his speaker fees are probably considered a worthwhile investment, even if in the
QA sessions don;t yield ways to learn how the Fed meetings really work.

PK writes:

"Easy money policies are directly detrimental ..to very wealthy .., the 0.01%"

Let's see:

From the NY Times:

"During his eight years as steward of the world’s largest economy, Mr. Bernanke’s salary was about $200,000 a year. Now he makes that in just a few hours speaking to bankers, hedge fund billionaires and leaders of industry. This year alone, he is poised to make millions of dollars from speaking engagements."

The 0.01 % now lavishly reward the author of policies that hurt them?

Really ??

If you believe this I have a bridge to sell you.
Of course, it would be appropriate if Hamas had refrained from initiating the all-out attack on Israel.  Unfortunately, Hamas acts with callous disregard for the lives of the people of Gaza.
Nothing here has anything to do with peace. The fact that that word is still used in this part of the world would be laughable if it weren't all so tragic.

In a family in which both parents are holding down full time jobs or in which the parent is single, the child is at day care or some sort of camp. Those institutions are not going to allow the child to wander off to explore. Weekends are devoted to running errands and/or religion. Again there is no time to explore.

Also, lack of trust is a huge factor. No one trusts anyone to treat children well. And as for older children, like pre teens, people don't trust them to behave properly and complain when children congregate around basketball courts or in fast food joints.
Good night, Chief.
I can't tell whether you're joking, but I fear that you're not.
Excellent and well-argued comment.
I agree.  So no hard feelings when Melo leaves right?
If you think many Knicks fans want Melo back, you have not been paying much attention.
times new roman or even courier new would have better choices.

I love the city of Cleveland, but the lingering anger towards LeBron is myopic and silly. James knew he needed a mentor, a role-model, and a player at or close to his equal: he found it in Dwayne Wade. (I know, Wade's been weak lately but he was killing it at the time of the move.) I'm sure Miami's joys didn't hurt, but LeBron was looking for a player or two who would be leaders as much or more than him. The Cavs couldn't bring on such a player.

Yes "the Decision" was rolled out in the worst way. But why can't Cleveland fans recognize that James's desire to learn on and off the court from someone like Wade was legit?

Plus, Dan Gilbert printed his attack-letter about LeBron in COMIC SANS typeface! That's messed up. I don't know if I could ever play for Gilbert after that. Time for Cleveland to mount a campaign to dump Gilbert, and send nothing but love to James.

This article was written by a reporter looking for his angle. It does not represent all of Cleveland. We have lives (very good quality, by the way) and we also can enjoy sports at the same time.

If Mr. James chooses not to come back to home, 99.9% of us will be okay. Don't worry about us.

And we are not pathetic -- to answer your question.

The people of Cleveland already have a life.  It's the media that tries to force the story that every Clevelander is obsessed with LeBron, or that the nation of Brazil has imploded because they lost a soccer game.  Normal people have more than one interest and they are more concerned about their own lives rather than the lives of sports stars.  Over July 4th weekend I visited my family in Cleveland and we had a great time at Cedar Point and eating at the restaurants in Little Italy.  I never heard LeBron's name mentioned once.

Cleveland, GET A LIFE. LBJ will do what is best for LBJ, just as any other person would do.

Are the people of Cleveland that pathetic that their lives revolve around what one overpaid jock does?

Come on Cleveland, you are better than that.

Not a valid analogy. The Palestinians are like a bad neighbor with a mad dog named Hamas they can't control or keep from coming into your backyard..

The dog doesn't want to bit you, it wasn't it kill you, It's not really that tough, just mean, ugly, angry and stubborn and likes to bark.

I know what i would do to the dog. And I'd make damn sure the neighbor does not get a new one.
"Turkey shoot in a barrel"? I would suggest the Turkeys stop firing deadly rockets from a barrel. Wait...what are turkeys doing in a barrel?

It is like Turkey Shoot in a barrel. The Obscenity of killing innocent people, and collective punishment of bull dozing  their homes with impunity. I have no qualms in saying that Netanyahu and his conservative cohorts just do not want the Palestinians to unite, let along them to have a state of there own.

I agree with this comment entirely, with one caveat.  Billions have been sent to Palestine by the United Nations, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and others.  Unfortunately, much of this money was misappropriated by corrupt officials, never reaching the Palestinians that it was intended to help.
Your history is all wrong. The Arabs never made an offer for two provinces or anything else other than Muslim domination of Dhimmis.
Oversize didn't occur to me but I pondered full and life before sizing up the correct KINGSIZE.
You seem to forget that Hamas launched this episode with the all-out bombing of Israel.  It is unfortunate that Hamas has wreaked this horror on the people of Gaza.

One rocket on Jerusalem or Tel Aviv is like saying one rocket on Manhattan or Washington DC.
Tel Aviv is full with skyscrapers loaded with innocent civilians and every rocket shot from Gaza to tell aviv is a potential mass killer.
and its sickening to see that there are some world leaders and media that have the audacity to tell Israel to "restrain" themselves after all the hundreds of rockets that the Palestinians are shooting at Israel in the last 48 hours

Hamas is not fighting the occupation, they do not accept the right of Israel to exist and have vowed to destroy it. For them regaining the west bank is only for the purpose of getting a more strategic area from which to attack Israel. Therefore the issue of the occupation has no relevance at all in regards to Hamas and Israel's action's against it.
The eradication of Hamas would be the best thing to happen to the Palestinian people, because its precisely because Hamas, which would continue to attack Israel from a Palestinian state, that Israel has legitimate security concerns about allowing such a state to happen.
